content:
Grandchild(ren) must be unemployed and unmarried and above three (3) months old but below eighteen (18) years or up to twenty-five (25) years of age, if studying full time in a recognized institution of higher learning at the commencement of this insurance. Age is calculated as at last birthday.

**For Annual Policy**
Family shall comprise of:
a. One (1) Adult and any number of the Adult's Child(ren); or
b. Two (2) Adults who are husband and wife and any number of their Child(ren).

For an annual plan for Family, You and the other Adult can travel independently. However, the Child(ren) must always be accompanied by either one (1) of the Adults under the same Policy.

### 12. Fraud, Misstatement or Concealment
Any fraud, misstatement or concealment in respect of this insurance or of any claim hereunder shall render this Policy null and void and any benefit due hereunder shall be or become forfeited.
questions: How does the policy define eligibility for grandchildren in terms of age, employment, marital status, and educational status at the commencement of insurance, and how is age calculated?
In an annual family policy, what are the permissible compositions of the family unit regarding adults and children, and how does this affect coverage eligibility?
Under the annual family plan, what are the travel requirements for the adults and children in terms of accompaniment and policy coverage when traveling independently or together?
How does the policy treat a grandchild who is over 18 but under 25 years old and studying full time at a recognized institution at the start of the insurance period?
What are the implications for coverage if a grandchild is married or employed, regardless of age, under this policy?
For an annual family policy, can two adults who are not husband and wife be covered together, and how does this affect the inclusion of children under the policy?
How does the policy handle the scenario where a child travels without either adult under the same policy in an annual family plan?
What are the consequences under the policy if any fraud, misstatement, or concealment is discovered in the insurance application or claim process?
How does the policy define the term 'Child' in the context of family composition for an annual policy, and what restrictions apply to their travel arrangements?
If a grandchild turns 18 during the policy period but was under 18 at commencement and unemployed and unmarried, how does the policy treat their coverage eligibility?
In the case of a family annual policy, can the adults travel separately without affecting the coverage of the children, and what conditions must be met for the children’s coverage to remain valid?
How does the policy’s fraud, misstatement, or concealment clause interact with claims made for grandchildren who do not meet the specified age or status criteria?
What documentation or proof might be required to verify a grandchild’s full-time student status at a recognized institution at the commencement of the insurance?
How does the policy calculate age for grandchildren and children when determining eligibility, and why is the last birthday used as the reference point?
What happens to the policy coverage if a child under the annual family plan is found to be traveling without being accompanied by either adult named in the policy?
How does the policy address coverage for grandchildren who are exactly three months old at the commencement of insurance, and what happens if they are younger?

In an annual family policy, if one adult is traveling separately from the other adult and the children, how does this affect the children’s requirement to be accompanied by an adult under the same policy?
What are the policy implications if a grandchild is unemployed and unmarried but not studying full time and is over 18 years old at the start of the insurance?
How does the fraud, misstatement, or concealment clause affect the validity of the entire policy versus individual claims, and what is the scope of forfeiture of benefits?
Can the policy be considered valid if a misstatement is made regarding the marital status or employment of a grandchild, and how does this impact claims related to that grandchild?
